sn35.232:4.1: At one time Venerable Sāriputta and Venerable Mahākoṭṭhita were staying near Benares, in the deer park at Isipatana.
sn35.232:4.2: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Mahākoṭṭhita came out of solitude, went to Venerable Sāriputta,
sn35.232:4.4: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side,
sn35.232:5.1: “Reverend Sāriputta, which is it? Is the eye the fetter of sights, or are sights the fetter of the eye?
sn35.232:5.2: Is the ear … nose … tongue … body …
sn35.232:5.3: mind the fetter of phenomena, or are phenomena the fetter of the mind?”
sn35.232:6.1: “Reverend Koṭṭhita, the eye is not the fetter of sights, nor are sights the fetter of the eye.
sn35.232:6.2: The fetter there is the desire and greed that arises from the pair of them.
sn35.232:6.5: mind is not the fetter of phenomena, nor are phenomena the fetter of the mind.

sn35.232:7.1: Suppose there was a black ox and a white ox yoked by a single harness or yoke.
sn35.232:7.2: Would it be right to say that
sn35.232:7.3: the black ox is the yoke of the white ox, or the white ox is the yoke of the black ox?”
sn35.232:7.5: The black ox is not the yoke of the white ox, nor is the white ox the yoke of the black ox.
sn35.232:7.6: The yoke there is the single harness or yoke that they’re yoked by.”

sn35.232:9.1: If the eye were the fetter of sights, or if sights were the fetter of the eye, this living of the spiritual life for the complete ending of suffering would not be found.

sn35.232:9.3: the fetter there is the desire and greed that arises from the pair of them, this living of the spiritual life for the complete ending of suffering is found.
